physicalObject: red Coca-Cola aluminum can
proxyLocation: near the top center of the table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Pinch the sidewall near the rim between thumb and index finger, wrap the remaining fingers around the body, and press inward to simulate squeezing (not sure whether it is applicable)

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This oil paint tube serves as a paint storage. Users would grasp it to squeeze out paint.
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Overall it would feel light weight about 30g
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Flattened cylinder about 2 cm in diameter.
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: User should feel the body as pliable and squeezable, deforming under pressure
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will pick up the paint tube with a one-handed precision grip, thumb and index/middle fingers pinching the crimped metal neck while the remaining fingers cradle the pliable body. To dispense paint they rotate or pull off the cap with a small twisting motion, then reposition the fingers to squeeze. The squeezing action is done by curling the distal phalanges, collapsing the soft metal body; the tube visibly deforms and internal resistance is felt until paint flow begins. Users may alternately use their other hand to roll the flat tail toward the nozzle for a final squeeze. After pressure is released the thin metal skin offers slight elastic recovery but largely stays flattened, giving the impression of a permanently deformed, light (≈30 g) object.

physicalObject: red Coca-Cola aluminum can
proxyLocation: near the top center of the table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Wrap your fingers around the side of the can, rest the index fingertip on the pull-tab, and press the tab downward while pointing the can forward

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Hold to spray
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: Spring-loaded index button (about 3mm travel) which is pressed straight downward.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: About 6cm wide to pinch
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user will pick up the cylindrical can with a one-handed power grip: fingers curl around the smooth metal side while the thumb stabilizes opposite the fingers. The index finger naturally extends to rest on the small spring-loaded actuator button at the nozzle. To use it, the wrist and forearm aim the can like a flashlight, then the index finger presses straight downward about 3 mm against the button’s light spring resistance. Continuous depression keeps the spray active; releasing the finger stops it. During spraying the hand stays mostly static except for fine wrist adjustments to direct the paint stream. Users may intermittently shake the can with a short forearm flick (keeping the same grip) to mix contents, producing a perceivable internal mass shift. The can itself remains rigid, with moderate inertia corresponding to a roughly 300 g metal cylinder; only the small plastic button moves, offering a soft click or detention at full travel.

physicalObject: red Coca-Cola aluminum can
proxyLocation: top center of the black table
utilizationMethod: Grip the can firmly around its middle with one hand and swing the bottom end downward in small striking motions (not sure whether it is applicable)

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Swing to deliver head strikes
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Round handle (about 3 cm Ø)
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users wrap their dominant hand around the wooden handle in a secure power grip, knuckles aligned with the striking axis. Because the stone/metal head is proportionally heavier than the handle, the object feels top-heavy; when lifted this creates a noticeable moment of inertia that encourages swinging from the elbow or shoulder. Striking involves controlled arcs, the wrist locking on impact. Upon contact with a chisel or stone surface, a short, high-frequency shock transmits through the rigid handle, and the head’s forward momentum momentarily arrests before rebound. Users may rotate the mallet in hand to alternate striking faces.

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users wrap their dominant hand around the wooden handle in a secure power grip, knuckles aligned with the striking axis. Because the stone/metal head is proportionally heavier than the handle, the object feels top-heavy; when lifted this creates a noticeable moment of inertia that encourages swinging from the elbow or shoulder. Striking involves controlled arcs, the wrist locking on impact. Upon contact with a chisel or stone surface, a short, high-frequency shock transmits through the rigid handle, and the head’s forward momentum momentarily arrests before rebound. Users may rotate the mallet in hand to alternate striking faces.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Struck with a mallet to remove material
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Oval shaft (about 2.5 cm in diameter)
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The chisel is held in the non-mallet hand with a pen-like precision grip or an overhand grip depending on force required. Thumb and index finger pinch the oval shaft 2–3 cm above the tip, other fingers stabilize along the sides; the opposite palm end (striking cap) is exposed. Users align the beveled tip on the stone, then keep the forearm rigid while the mallet hand delivers blows. Each impact sends a sharp vibration down the metal shaft into the fingers, but the high rigidity stops visible deformation. Between strikes, users may slide or pivot the tip slightly to reposition, scraping sounds and resistance providing feedback. The tool feels cool and moderately heavy (~400 g), encouraging deliberate movements.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: It serves as an artistic tool for painting. Users would make controlled strokes across canvas surfaces.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel the cylindrical handle (1cm diameter) with smooth, rounded edges.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users hold the slender 1 cm handle with a pen or tripod grip between thumb, index, and middle fingers, enabling fine wrist and finger articulation. Strokes are produced by rolling the handle between fingertips and varying pressure—light touches for thin lines, firmer presses for broader coverage. The lightweight shaft offers minimal inertia, while soft bristles compress and fan out when they meet the canvas, giving a gentle give-and-release sensation. Users often flip or rotate the brush to change angle, occasionally tapping it against a palette to unload excess paint.

physicalObject: black and silver extendable selfie stick with phone holder
proxyLocation: lying diagonally across the table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hold the rubberized hand-grip near its end with a relaxed pen-style grip and guide the extended rod’s tip across an imaginary surface as if painting

virtualObjectInfo.usage: It serves as an artistic tool for painting. Users would make controlled strokes across canvas surfaces.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel the cylindrical handle (1cm diameter) with smooth, rounded edges.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users hold the slender 1 cm handle with a pen or tripod grip between thumb, index, and middle fingers, enabling fine wrist and finger articulation. Strokes are produced by rolling the handle between fingertips and varying pressure—light touches for thin lines, firmer presses for broader coverage. The lightweight shaft offers minimal inertia, while soft bristles compress and fan out when they meet the canvas, giving a gentle give-and-release sensation. Users often flip or rotate the brush to change angle, occasionally tapping it against a palette to unload excess paint.

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The tablet acts as an immobile contact surface rather than something to grasp. Users position it horizontally or vertically in the scene and then apply tools (chisel, brush) against it. Primary body part involved is the tool-held hand; indirect contact is felt through the tool when it presses, scrapes, or is struck. Interaction is characterized by repeated point impacts (chisel strikes) and occasional sliding or brushing motions. The stone provides high hardness, zero give, and coarse texture, reflecting vibrations back through the tool on every contact.

Elbow and shoulder contribute larger, smooth, linear sweeps when painting broad areas, while shorter wrist-centric strokes allow detail work near edges. Throughout the motion the user senses moderate inertial load that concentrates toward the roller head; as direction reverses, this mass lags slightly, conveying the feel of a rotating drum mounted on a light wire frame. Haptically, the handle feels hard and smooth with minimal give, while the fingers detect the narrow cylindrical outline. When the virtual roller contacts a surface, users expect very low resistance to rolling (axle spins freely), so physical feedback would be a light, continuous vibration or minimal friction, reinforcing that the roller drum is turning rather than sliding. No squeezing or trigger actions are required—interaction is dominated by sustained gripping, repetitive arm swings, and subtle wrist adjustments, with the virtual object visually laying paint as it responds by rotating in sync with the user’s strokes.
